intro: Polylepis triacontandra, commonly known as the Andean wax tree, is a species of flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes. It belongs to the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its thick, waxy leaves that help it withstand harsh environmental conditions. The tree can grow up to 20 meters tall and is often found in cloud forests at elevations between 2,500 and 4,000 meters. Its bark is thick and fibrous, providing structural support and protection against strong winds and temperature fluctuations. Polylepis triacontandra plays an important ecological role in its habitat, offering shelter and food for various wildlife species.
